definitions.definition: either of two equal parts into which something is or can be divided

examples.text: two and a half kilos *(= 2½)*
One and a half hours are allowed for the exam.
An hour and a half is allowed for the exam.
in the **first half** of the 20th century
The **second half** of the book is more exciting.
The **two halves** of the city were reunited in 1990.
the left half of the brain
the lower half of the window
the northern half of the country
I've divided the money in half.
We'll need to reduce the weight by half.
Cut the remaining half into large chunks.
Over a half of all accidents happen in the home.
She's four and a half years old now.
in the latter half of the 19th century
the rear half of the car
We split the work half and half.

definitions.definition: either of two periods of time into which a sports game, concert, etc. is divided

examples.text: No goals were scored **in the first half**.
She played well **in the second half** of the match.
He made two superb saves in the first two minutes of the half.
We had a few chances to score in both halves.

definitions.definition: one of the defending players in hockey or rugby whose position is between those who play at the front of a team and those who play at the back
one of the two attacking players in American football whose position is behind the quarterback and next to the full backs
the position a half back plays at (also called a tailback in American football)
half a pint (= 0.568 of a litre in the UK and some other countries, and 0.473 of a litre in the US) of beer or a similar drink

examples.text: Two halves of bitter, please.

definitions.definition: bigger, better, more important, etc. than usual

examples.text: That was a game and a half!

definitions.definition: to do whatever you do completely and to the greatest possible degree

examples.text: You're expecting twins? Well, you never did do anything by halves.

definitions.definition: to share the cost of something equally with somebody

examples.text: We go halves on all the bills.

definitions.definition: used in negative sentences to say that a situation is worse or more complicated than somebody thinks

examples.text: ‘It sounds very difficult.’ ‘**You don't know the half of it**.’

definitions.definition: used to say that you think you will do something, although you are not sure

examples.text: I've half a mind to come with you tomorrow.

definitions.definition: used to say that you think that what somebody has done is bad and should do something about it, although you probably will not

examples.text: I've a good mind to write and tell your parents about it.

definitions.definition: the way of life of a different social group, especially one much richer than you
used to say that there is not much real difference between two possible choices
one and a half times the usual rate of pay

examples.text: We get time and a half on Sundays.

definitions.definition: clever, etc. in a way that annoys you or makes you not trust somebody/something

wordOrigin: Old English half, healf, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch half and German halb (adjectives). The earliest meaning of the Germanic base was ‘side’, also a noun sense in Old English.
